newsitem.title: USA: Fidelity executive quits to join holding company.
newsitem.headline: Fidelity executive quits to join holding company.

text.p: Affiliated Managers Group (AMG) said Brian Girvan, chief financial officer of Fidelity Investments Institutional Services, has quit Fidelity to join AMG.
Girvan will be chief financial officer and senior vice president of the privately-held, Boston-based holding company which invests in prominent, mid-sized money management firms, AMG said.
Girvan told Reuters in an interview that his decision to leave Fidelity after one and a half "had nothing to do with compensation."
"It wasn't really leaving Fidelity, it was joining AMG," he said. "I like the buisness model, and I like the work, the job. This will be closer to the capital markets, which is work that I enjoy."
AMG said in the release that its partnership structure allows the firm's management to retain or receive significant, direct ownership in the company.
Fidelity Investments Institutional Services sells mutual funds indirectly to the retail market through broker-dealers, banks, insurance companies and registered investment professionals, he said.
Girvan's departure comes at a time when a number of fund managers have also left the mutual fund company. But he said he knew nothing about the reasons for their departures.

"As our business has grown to seven affiliates totaling $20 billion in assets under management, we felt that someone of Brian's experience and ability would make a significant contribution to the firm and to our affiliates," William Nutt, President and Chief Executive Officer of AMG, said in a statement.
A Fidelity spokeswoman said that the company would fill Girvan's post shortly.
